meeting_context:
# North Star & Strategic Context

This file combines the overall project mission (North Star) and summaries of key strategic documents for use in AI prompts, particularly for the AI Agent Council context generation.

**Last Updated:** December 2025

---

**North Star:**
To build the most reliable, developer-friendly open-source AI agent framework and cloud platform—enabling builders worldwide to deploy autonomous agents that work seamlessly across chains and platforms. We create infrastructure where agents and humans collaborate, forming the foundation for a decentralized AI economy that accelerates the path toward beneficial AGI.

---

**Core Principles:**
1. **Execution Excellence** - Reliability and seamless UX over feature quantity
2. **Developer First** - Great DX attracts builders; builders create ecosystem value
3. **Open & Composable** - Multi-agent systems that interoperate across platforms
4. **Trust Through Shipping** - Build community confidence through consistent delivery

---

**Current Product Focus (Dec 2025):**
- **ElizaOS Framework** (v1.6.x) - The core TypeScript toolkit for building persistent, interoperable agents
- **ElizaOS Cloud** - Managed deployment platform with integrated storage and cross-chain capabilities
- **Flagship Agents** - Reference implementations (Eli5, Otaku) demonstrating platform capabilities
- **Cross-Chain Infrastructure** - Native support for multi-chain agent operations via Jeju/x402

---

**ElizaOS Mission Summary:**
ElizaOS is an open-source "operating system for AI agents" aimed at decentralizing AI development. Built on three pillars: 1) The Eliza Framework (TypeScript toolkit for persistent agents), 2) AI-Enhanced Governance (building toward autonomous DAOs), and 3) Eliza Labs (R&D driving cloud, cross-chain, and multi-agent capabilities). The native token coordinates the ecosystem. The vision is an intelligent internet built on open protocols and collaboration.

---

**Taming Information Summary:**
Addresses the challenge of information scattered across platforms (Discord, GitHub, X). Uses AI agents as "bridges" to collect, wrangle (summarize/tag), and distribute information in various formats (JSON, MD, RSS, dashboards, council episodes). Treats documentation as a first-class citizen to empower AI assistants and streamline community operations.
monthly_goal: December 2025: Execution excellence—complete token migration with high success rate, launch ElizaOS Cloud, stabilize flagship agents, and build developer trust through reliability and clear documentation.
daily_focus: Council attention is pulled between high-visibility narrative momentum (token chatter and “Zelda with agents” visions) and a critical execution gap: unresolved migration FAQs and near-zero observable core repo throughput during the latest window.

key_points.summary: Discord shows repeated migration/contract questions going unanswered, creating an avoidable trust deficit precisely during an “execution excellence” directive; documentation and in-product guidance must close the loop.

deliberation_items.text: What is the Council’s minimum acceptable standard for migration clarity (contract address, deadline, step-by-step flows) and where must it be surfaced (docs, website, in-app, Discord bot)?
context: 💬-discussion: "Where do I find the token contract for 'elizaOS'?" (BoulderMagic) — Unanswered
💬-discussion: "When is the deadline for manually swapping ai16z tokens… to elizaos tokens?" (KARA) — Unanswered

answer_1.text: Publish a single canonical “Migration Console” page (contract addresses, deadlines, wallet-specific steps) and mirror it in Discord via a bot command.
answer_1.implication: Reduces repeated support load and stabilizes trust by making answers deterministic and shareable.

answer_2.text: Rely on community channels (#migration-help, pinned messages) and address edge cases ad hoc as they appear.
answer_2.implication: Maintains flexibility but prolongs uncertainty and increases rumor-driven sentiment swings.

answer_3.text: Embed migration checks directly into ElizaOS Cloud/CLI login flow (detect holdings, guide swaps) and treat docs as secondary.
answer_3.implication: Best UX if built quickly, but risks schedule impact on Cloud launch if engineering scope expands.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: Should token utility messaging be formally coupled to Cloud launch (explicit integrations/benefits), or kept decoupled until Cloud reliability is proven?
context: 💬-discussion: "I saw someone asked in X why ElisaOS token is not integrated into cloud?" (chomppp) — Unanswered
2026-01-01 Discord highlights: "Create documentation explaining token integration with cloud services" (Mentioned by chomppp)

answer_1.text: Couple messaging: define 1–2 concrete Cloud utilities gated/discounted by token from day one, and document them as part of launch.
answer_1.implication: Creates clear demand narrative, but increases coordination and reliability requirements at launch.

answer_2.text: Decouple: launch Cloud purely on reliability/DX, and publish token utility roadmap with explicit milestones and timelines.
answer_2.implication: Aligns with execution excellence; reduces launch risk while still giving holders a credible plan.

answer_3.text: Soft-couple: communicate “token hooks are coming” without specifying utilities until post-launch telemetry validates Cloud stability.
answer_3.implication: Minimizes immediate commitments but may be perceived as evasive by a token-focused segment.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How should the Council respond to buyback speculation to avoid governance-by-rumor while preserving strategic optionality?
context: Daily report 2026-01-01: "discussions about potential buyback programs… strategic versus programmatic buybacks"
Community tone: predictions of "Coinbase listing" and new ATHs (2026-01-01 daily summary)

answer_1.text: Issue a governance stance: buybacks are not planned; focus is migration + Cloud launch; revisit only after revenue signals.
answer_1.implication: Quiets speculation and reinforces execution priorities, but may dampen short-term market enthusiasm.

answer_2.text: Define a conditional framework (e.g., revenue thresholds, treasury policy) without committing to execution.
answer_2.implication: Channels speculation into measurable criteria while keeping strategic flexibility.

answer_3.text: Allow community-led narrative to run; no official commentary beyond pointing to tokenomics docs.
answer_3.implication: Avoids distraction for core team but cedes narrative control and increases misinformation risk.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.summary: Operational telemetry shows a temporary dead zone in core repo activity (no PRs/issues/contributors in the tracked window), conflicting with the mandate to build trust through shipping; Council should verify whether this is a measurement artifact, a holiday pause, or a systemic bottleneck.

deliberation_items.text: Is the observed “0 PRs / 0 contributors” in the elizaos/eliza window an actual slowdown or a reporting/observability gap, and who owns closing that ambiguity?
context: GitHub Activity Summary: "From January 1-2, 2026, the elizaos/eliza repository had no new pull requests (0 merged), no new issues, and no active contributors."
Monthly interval report (generated): "0 new PRs… 0 active contributors."

answer_1.text: Treat as a data quality issue: audit telemetry pipeline and cross-check with GitHub directly; assign an owner today.
answer_1.implication: Protects Council decision-making from false negatives and strengthens “trust through shipping” instrumentation.

answer_2.text: Assume it’s a holiday pause; set an explicit restart cadence and public weekly ship targets starting next workday.
answer_2.implication: Keeps focus on momentum without over-investing in tooling, but risks missing real blockers.

answer_3.text: Assume it’s a real throughput problem; immediately re-plan scope (freeze non-critical work) around Cloud + migration deliverables.
answer_3.implication: Maximizes execution excellence, but may prematurely constrain R&D if the signal is misleading.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: What is the Council’s near-term definition of “shipping” that restores trust: releases, uptime, migration success rate, or developer onboarding completion?
context: Core Principles: "Trust Through Shipping" and "Execution Excellence"
Monthly directive emphasis: "launch ElizaOS Cloud… stabilize flagship agents… clear documentation"

answer_1.text: Release-centric: commit to a fixed cadence (e.g., weekly tagged releases across core + critical plugins).
answer_1.implication: Creates visible momentum for devs, but can incentivize shallow shipping if quality gates are weak.

answer_2.text: Reliability-centric: publish Cloud SLOs + flagship agent stability metrics; shipping equals meeting SLOs for consecutive weeks.
answer_2.implication: Aligns tightly with North Star reliability, though less flashy for community perception.

answer_3.text: Journey-centric: shipping equals “migration completed + docs + onboarding tutorial works end-to-end,” even if releases are fewer.
answer_3.implication: Maximizes user outcomes and reduces support burden, but may under-serve power-user feature expectations.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How aggressively should the Council enforce scope discipline when community attention drifts to speculative or side projects?
context: Discord 2026-01-01: many New Year/token discussions; migration questions unanswered
Core-devs: significant energy on gaming concepts (RuneScape/Zelda with agents)

answer_1.text: Hard gate: only Cloud/migration/flagship stability work is sanctioned until success metrics are met.
answer_1.implication: Highest probability of meeting the directive, but may reduce morale and external narrative excitement.

answer_2.text: Portfolio approach: reserve a small, time-boxed R&D lane (e.g., 10–15%) for high-EV experiments while protecting core lanes.
answer_2.implication: Sustains innovation and narrative while keeping execution primary, but requires strong project management.

answer_3.text: Community-led experimentation: encourage external contributors to drive side projects; core team provides interfaces and plugin hooks only.
answer_3.implication: Preserves core focus and accelerates ecosystem growth if governance and review bandwidth exist.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.topic: Gaming/Megaverse Opportunity vs Core Platform Priorities
key_points.summary: Core-devs surfaced strong interest (including VC inbound) in a RuneScape/Zelda-like agent game and Hyperscape tooling needs; Council must decide whether this becomes a flagship reference vertical (showcasing multi-agent autonomy) or remains a secondary community experiment.

deliberation_items.text: Should “Zelda with agents” be elevated into an official flagship reference (to demonstrate multi-agent autonomy), or kept as a side project until Cloud is stable?
context: core-devs (Shaw): "VCs have reached out… enthusiastic for the RuneScape-inspired project."
core-devs (Shaw): "Zelda with agents" via forking RuneScape

answer_1.text: Elevate now: declare it a flagship vertical with a clear MVP that showcases agents generating quests/NPC behavior on Cloud.
answer_1.implication: Could become the most compelling demo for builders/investors, but risks distracting from Cloud hardening.

answer_2.text: Defer: keep it experimental until Cloud/migration KPIs are met; then adopt as a post-launch flagship.
answer_2.implication: Protects execution excellence while preserving a strong narrative asset for later amplification.

answer_3.text: Split ownership: core defines interfaces + minimal support; community/partners build the game; Council blesses it as “ecosystem-led.”
answer_3.implication: Maximizes composability and ecosystem leverage, but quality control and brand risk must be managed.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: What is the correct technical “first brick” for the Hyperscape/agent game vision: agent-mode sandbox, quest/NPC authoring tools, or world editing/inspection?
context: core-devs (Shaw): "asset forge in hyperscape" needs "quest generation" and "NPC setup"
Action item: "Implement agent mode in RuneScape fork where users can create agents and watch them run around"

answer_1.text: Start with agent-mode sandbox (spawn agents, observe behavior, instrumentation) to validate reliability and emergent behavior first.
answer_1.implication: Creates a developer-first testbed and hard data for autonomy, enabling disciplined iteration.

answer_2.text: Start with quest generation + NPC authoring to produce immediate gameplay content and demo value.
answer_2.implication: Fast narrative payoff, but may mask underlying agent reliability gaps until later.

answer_3.text: Start with world viewing/tweaking tooling to ensure creators can debug and control simulations before adding autonomy.
answer_3.implication: Reduces downstream rework and improves UX, but delays the “agents feel alive” moment.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How should Council integrate external capital interest (VC inbound) without compromising open-source credibility and shipping discipline?
context: core-devs (Shaw): VCs expressed interest in the RuneScape project
Core Principles: "Open & Composable" and "Trust Through Shipping"

answer_1.text: Accept capital only if it directly funds Cloud reliability and open-source deliverables (SLOs, docs, plugin hardening).
answer_1.implication: Aligns incentives to North Star and reduces risk of narrative-driven detours.

answer_2.text: Ring-fence capital into a separate “Labs” track for gaming demos, keeping core platform roadmap unchanged.
answer_2.implication: Enables parallel innovation, but requires governance to prevent brand confusion and resource bleed.

answer_3.text: Decline/ignore VC interest until after Cloud launch and migration completion; revisit with stronger leverage later.
answer_3.implication: Maximizes focus and bargaining power, but may miss a window for rapid ecosystem expansion.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.
